content.description: Sit Start on the right face and climb the face and topout. I have the original starting hold on my back deck if anyone wants to glue it back on!

Sit start on the right arrete, using right hands and heel hooks along the arrete while the left hand starts on crimps and moves its way up the face to the jugs near the top. Top out is comfortable though the landing isn't the best. Crux will be the first move or two off the ground when the left hand has few good options.
content.location: On the far right side of the main boudler

content.description: Climb the right most arete to the horizontal then traverse left across the entire face and mantle out past the overhanging tree.

While most of the routes on this rock are tougher and rated higher - for those that are just starting out, outdoors and want an easier problem - this is likely somewhere between V-easy and V0- 

 There are tons of different lines you can use to add some slight difficulty, or to make it easier. A top out is easy to do and you can walk off the back corner. Would recommend folding pad in half and placing it between the two rock faces. It is pretty mossy relative to the main face of the boulder, but I didn't experience any slipping - some great foot holds and hand holds, some are crimpier
content.location: All the way on the right hand side of the main boulder, around the corner.

content.description: Sit start with left hand on a crappy crimp and right hand on a sharp side pull with feet down low. Move straight up to a crystal ledge with the left and a more comfortable side pull with the right before gaining the big jug at the top and an easy top-out. Each move is easier than the one before and the start is the hardest part.Named because this route is a confidence booster on an otherwise very stiff wall. Easiest sit start we've found so far.
content.location: Just to the left of the bulging middle arete of the wall

content.description: On the Entrance boulder sit start using small crimps just to the right of the overhanging tree fire straight up to the horizontal on tiny crimps and over the lip of the rock.

This is the 'main wall' at Babcock Preserve. 8 to 10 unique lines ranging from easy warm-ups to V6 and higher, some with clean, easy top-outs and some much trickier. The wall is uniformly about 10-12ft to the lip all overhung. Great place to get a good workout and get comfortable with topping out but with solid landings all around. Rock is quite sharp so your fingers might need some time to adjust.
